newsitem.title: USA: Tibco to unveil more 'push' software pacts.
newsitem.headline: Tibco to unveil more 'push' software pacts.

text.p: Tibco Inc. on Monday will announce that at least 10 more computer companies, including International Business Machines Corp., have agreed to use its software for distributing information through the Internet.

The company writes software that automatically routes -- or "pushes" -- financial information, news and other data from a publisher to an individual personal computer. The software works on corporate or public computer networks.
Tibco has been trying for the past year to make its push software one of the standards for sending information through the Internet.
Several companies said in December they would use Tibco technology, including Cisco Systems Inc., the biggest maker of computer networking equipment.
The company will announce on Monday a second round of partnerships that will help it establish its software as a standard, Tibco executives said.
Tibco, based in Palo Alto, Calif., is a unit of Reuters Holding Plc, the parent company of the Reuters news agency.
IBM and network equipment company 3Com Corp. are expected to be two of the company's new partners.
"We started this with Cisco. We are now expanding this throughout the network and the computing value chain," Tibco Chairman and Chief Executive Vivek Ranadive said.
IBM is expected to announce that its IBM Global Services unit will help sell Tibco software and install it in the networks of IBM customers.
3Com is expected to announce it will put Tibco software in its networking cards, the devices that link personal computers to networks.
Other companies expected to sign up include Backweb, Lanacom, Airmedia, Autonomy, First Floor, Elemental Software, Vxtreme, Starburst and Interweave, Tibco said.
Tibco's technology competes against offerings from Marimba Inc., Microsoft Corp. and Netscape Communications Inc.
